description: Age of the customer, as older customers may be more likely to stay with the account.
Length of time the customer has had the account, as longer tenure may indicate higher likelihood of retention.
Amount the customer is charged each month, as higher charges may lead to higher churn rates.
Number of customer support calls made by the customer, as more calls may indicate dissatisfaction and potential churn.
Type of contract (e.g., month-to-month, annual), as different contract lengths may impact likelihood of churn.
How often the customer uses the service, as higher usage may indicate lower likelihood of churn.
Availability of competitive offers in the market, as the presence of attractive alternatives may increase churn rate.
Feedback or satisfaction scores provided by the customer, as lower satisfaction may indicate higher likelihood of churn.
Occurrence of billing issues, as unresolved issues may lead to customer dissatisfaction and churn.
Utilization of add-on services or features, as higher usage may indicate lower likelihood of churn.
The payment method used by the customer, as certain methods may be associated with higher churn rates.
Occurrence of significant life events (e.g., marriage, new job) that may impact customer's decision to stay or churn.
The speed of the internet connection, as slower connections may lead to dissatisfaction and churn.
Availability of renewal offers at the end of the contract term, as attractive offers may impact customer retention.
Level of engagement with the company's social media channels, as active engagement may be a positive sign for retention.
The number of people in the customer's household, as larger households may be less likely to churn.
Whether the customer has recently relocated, as relocation may impact the decision to continue with the account.
The rate at which the customer opens and engages with company emails, as higher engagement may indicate lower churn likelihood.
The extent to which the customer has referred others to the service, as strong referrals may indicate lower churn rates.
Customer's sensitivity towards pricing changes, as more price-sensitive customers may be more likely to churn.
Number of formal complaints filed by the customer, as higher complaints may lead to increased likelihood of churn.
Participation in loyalty programs offered by the company, as active participation may indicate lower likelihood of churn.
Quality of technical support provided to the customer, as poor support may impact retention negatively.
Compatibility of the service with the customer's devices, as compatibility issues may lead to dissatisfaction and churn.
Participation in family plans or shared accounts, as shared plans may lead to lower likelihood of churn.
Variability in the customer's account usage patterns, as consistent usage may indicate lower likelihood of churn.
The credit score of the customer, as higher credit scores may be associated with lower churn rates.
Overall market trends and competition, as changes in the market may impact customer retention.
Perceived quality of the service or product offered, as higher quality may lead to lower likelihood of churn.
The educational level of the customer, as higher education levels may be associated with lower churn rates.
